About

I am a musician/ instructor based out of Fargo, ND with a passion for creating things whether it be through playing music, teaching, or computer code. Constantly curious about the world around me and perpetually driven to problem solving.

When I'm not playing music or coding you can find me hanging out with my family. We enjoy cooking/ eating good food, watching movies, going for walks in the park, and going to the lakes during the summer season.

Around the Web

Copyright © Steve's Personal Portfolio 2021

LessonsWith

For my solo project, I leaned on my 10+ years of teaching experience to drive me to create an app that connects a teacher with their student. The highlight feature for this app is the student's Practice Log where they can keep track of their pratice routines by filling out a simple form. The log is stored in an archive for the student to view later as well as their respective teacher to look at to see what the student has been working on over the week. I used React, Bootstrap, Express, Redux, Nod.js, and PostgresSQL for this project.

View Code

Awesome Calculator

In this project, I used the knowledge I gained from that week's lessons on building an app from the server side. All logic for the calculator is written in the backend on the server then brought through by jQuery and displayed on the DOM from the index.html file. I had a lot of fun solving the logic problem of building a functioning calculator that does basic math. I also really enjoyed stlying it up a bit to make it POP!

View Website
View Code

TaDa!

I built a basic ToDo app that I call "TaDa!" where you can turn your ToDos into TaDas. This was a weekend challenge in which I was assigned the task to create a Todo app that uses a PostgresSQL database to store the data. This was the first challenge where were supposed to think about making a CRUD app. I used Postico to write queries and transfer data about the task description and whether it was completed. It also has a delete function to it as well. In this project, I also became more comfortable with conditionally rendering something on the DOM using jQuery. In this case, a green block that say "TaDa!" renders when the user clicks on "Complete".

View Website
